Award.AwardTitle: Secondary Science Teaching with English Language and Literacy Acquisition (SSTELLA)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a four-year Discovery Research K-12 project to develop, implement, and study an experimental model of secondary science pre-service teacher education designed to prepare novice school teachers to provide effective science instruction to English language learners (ELLs). The project incorporates the principles underlying the Next Generation Science Standards with a focus on promoting students' scientific sense-making, comprehension and communication of scientific discourse, and productive use of language. It articulates theory and practice related to the teaching of science content and the development of English language and literacy, and provides teachers with models of integrated practice in video cases and curriculum units. To test the efficacy of the study, a longitudinal, mixed-methods, quasi-experimental study is conducted at four institutions: the University of California-Santa Cruz, Arizona State University, the University of Arizona, and the University of Texas-San Antonio.

The three research questions are: (1) What is the impact of the project's pre-service teacher education program on novice secondary science teachers' knowledge, beliefs, and practice from the pre-service program into the second year of teaching?; (2) What is the relationship between science method instructors' fidelity of implementation of the project's practices and novice teachers' outcomes (knowledge, beliefs, and practice)?; and (3) What is the relationship between novice teachers' implementation of project-promoted practices and their students' learning? To answer these questions, the project collects and analyzes quantitative and qualitative data on novice teachers (85 treatment group and 85 control group) over three years utilizing surveys, interviews, observations, and student assessment instruments. Teachers' beliefs and knowledge about teaching science to ELLs are measured using the project-developed Science Teaching Survey, which provides quantitative scores based on a Likert-type scale, and the science teacher interview protocol to provide qualitative data, including the contextual factors affecting implementation of project-promoted practices. Classroom observations are captured through qualitative field notes and the Classroom Observation Rubric--a systematic project-developed observation instrument that measures implementation of the practices. Student learning outcomes are measured using (a) the Woodcock-Mu√±oz Language Survey (students' proficiency at applying listening, reading, writing, and comprehension abilities); (b) the Literacy in Science Assessment (students' productive use of language in authentic science literacy tasks); (c) the Scientific Sense-Making Assessment (how students make sense of core science ideas through scientific and engineering practices); and (d) appropriate state standardized assessments. In addition, the Opportunity to Learn Survey gauges students' perceptions of implementation of literacy integration, motivation in class, and identity as readers.

Project outcomes are: (a) a research-based and field-tested model for pre-service secondary science teacher education, including resources for science methods courses instructors and pre-service teachers; and (b) valid and reliable instrumentation usable in similar research and development environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Across the nation, future middle and high school (or secondary) science teachers enroll in university teacher preparation programs where they take courses and engage in field experiences to prepare them to develop safe and supportive learning environments, teach their particular content, and learn to teach in culturally, linguistically, and socially diverse classroom settings. However, few teacher preparation models exist that draw on the most recent and compelling literature around teaching science to English Learners (i.e., students still developing the English needed to be successful in science coursework). Moreover, the extant literature has not fully tested such models across multiple programs for its impact on teachers and students. The Secondary Science Teaching with English Language and Literacy Acquisition (or SSTELLA) addressed this critical, yet underdeveloped research area by accomplishing three goals. First, we developed and implemented (twice) a secondary science teacher preparation intervention (i.e., a restructured science teaching methods course; professional development for university supervisors and school district cooperating teachers) based on empirically supported effective practices that integrate English language and literacy development into rigorous, authentic, and contextualized science instruction (i.e., the SSTELLA Framework) at four universities in California, Arizona, and Texas. Second, we developed a set of science teacher education instructional tools, including video cases and model science lessons, to exemplify the SSTELLA Framework and enable PST educators and school district professional developers to implement for a broader range of teachers. Finally, we conducted  a mixed methods quasi-experimental longitudinal research study with participating PSTs to understand the intervention?s impact on teachers? knowledge/beliefs, practices, as well as relationships to science method instructor teaching and secondary students? science learning. PSTs who participated in the SSTELLA Intervention (Implementation Group #1 [n=40]; Implementation Group #2 [n=40]) were compared to those who participated in the secondary science method course at the same universities the year prior to implementation (Baseline Control group [n=55]). All research instruments aligned to the SSTELLA Framework, providing us with a means in which to look across survey, interview, and observation databases. 

 

Overall, we found evidence across the various datasets that collectively suggest the positive impact of the SSTELLA interview on the participating PSTs. First, as measured by the Pre/Post SSTELLA Science Teacher Survey and coding the Pre/Post SSTELLA Science Teacher Interview, on average preservice teachers who participated in the SSTELLA Intervention over the two years of implementation positively changed in their knowledge/beliefs toward using SSTELLA Instructional Practices. This change was statistically significant when compared to the Baseline Control Group.  Results also reveal how differences from the baseline control were typically greater for the Implementation Group #2. As measured by the SSTELLA Classroom Observation Rubric, we found two SSTELLA instructional practices with particularly high fidelity: (1)Facilitating productive student talk and (2) Promoting widespread student interaction. By fidelity, we mean that a majority of treatment PSTs implemented the practice at a high level and implemented on average scored higher than the control group.

 

We also considered, and expected there to be variation across the implementations sites. As measured by the SSTELLA Science Method Observation Rubric (SMOR), we actually found little variation in how instructors teaching the restructured secondary science method course modeled SSTELLA instructional practices for the PSTs, although we found some variation in how instructors provided opportunities for PSTs? pedagogical development around the practices. Regarding changes in PST knowledge/beliefs toward SSTELLA Practices and implementation of the practices, we found variation by site both within the treatment group and between control and treatment group. One program in particular demonstrated the highest magnitude of change across various instructional practices. By the second implementation the change was maintained, but variation decreased across sites. Finally, by studying student learning outcomes from a subgroup (n=16) of the original participants in their second year of teaching, we found that there is a statistically significant relationship between the implementation of SSTELLA practices and learning outcomes in conceptual understanding, reading, and writing (as measured by the SSTELLA Science Assessment), including English Learners? learning.

 

In conclusion, SSTELLA set out to improve upon how novice secondary science teachers are prepared to teach English Learners, and in the process all students, by developing and implementing an intervention that attends to the reciprocal and synergistic nature of learning science and developing language and literacy. Results suggest the positive impact the intervention had on participating PSTs? knowledge/beliefs and practice toward teaching science to ELs. More importantly, the results were consistent across multiple implementation groups and across multiple teacher preparation programs with distinct institutional and geographic contexts. SSTELLA generated an array of instructional tools that are available for science teacher educators across the nation and a cohesive set of research instruments that can aid future large scale projects in studying impact across multiple data sources and sites.
